nodes.bodyText:
You don't need the indirection..
    gauge = io.micrometer.core.instrument.Gauge.builder(metricInfo.name(), longAdder, LongAdder::doubleValue)
Execution of this step should still be guarded as others are.

Why exactly is it useful to wrap it into a BooleanSupplier that checks whether the configuration enables it, instead of simply doing the same by an if condition in the method? Other extensions do it this way, including those where you wrote this code (HibernateOrmMetricsProcessor).
Why is reflection necessary for these classes? I'm missing something
I don't know, but without this, native mode breaks.
I would like to understand where these values come from. Negative values don't seem correct for an out-of-the-box default. Can we talk through this?

The expiry and bufferLength, I just guessed. Perhaps they should be configurable?
Not sure what you mean by negative values. There are no negative values. Double.MIN_VALUE is greater than zero.
You're right. I forgot that Double doesn't work that way 🤦‍♀️
Mark this one resolved. ;)

p50 getSnapshot().getMedian()
p75 getSnapshot().get75thPercentile()
p95 getSnapshot().get95thPercentile()
p98 getSnapshot().get98thPercentile()
p99 getSnapshot().get99thPercentile()
p999 getSnapshot().get999thPercentile()
?

One thing we could consider is not publishing the percentiles by default (but publish the other calculations), and rely on the usual MeterFilter behavior for users to turn those on.. the memory implications for using histograms isn't trivial.

I added the missing 99.9%.
Whether to publish percentiles by default, I'd say yes, since we are trying to emulate the MP Metrics exporter, which does that always 🐰
This one is resolved, too. ;)

Given what this does (retrieve from collection effectively retrieves from the stream repeatedly), I think you should rejigger this to use the match function on the Meter interface as is done here:
https://github.com/micrometer-metrics/micrometer/blob/master/implementations/micrometer-registry-appoptics/src/main/java/io/micrometer/appoptics/AppOpticsMeterRegistry.java#L98
(most other registries do this as well).
Gives you a one time loop through everything that you can use to initialize those collections with what you need, and then you can emit the lot at the end.

Given that the Meter.match method takes functions that act on only one meter at a time (and I need to group the meters by name and type first to be able to export), I don't see any other use for it than for potentially performing the grouping itself, but it would feel quite awkward and we can do that more effectively using pure Java streams.. So I guess I'd need more hints how you imagine doing this?!

Well. The way it exists now, you're iterating the list of registered meters several times: registry.getMeters().stream() in retrieveFromCollection. The above does that iteration/collection in one fell swoop.
Ok, I committed this change.
See other comment -- not sure why this step is necessary.
WOOHOO! =)
AtomicLong or LongAdder?
I basically copied this over from Micrometer's CumulativeDistributionSummary and they have an AtomicLong there ;) but yes this is probably a good idea, will change
Javadoc doesn't match the actual config default. Which should it be?
Good catch, changed the javadoc to /metrics
Thanks!
I might have missed this somewhere, but should the content type be changed? I thought "004" was the right one for Prometheus?

Jan and I talked about this one. Due to precedence order, it's safer to use text plain... if the suffix (for type 004 is there), it gets weird with JSON being on the same endpoint.
Can two types be produced in different orders? (text/plain at order(1) AND 004)?

This is only for handler matching purposes, this is not what will be sent to the client. The actual content type is set in the handler: https://github.com/quarkusio/quarkus/blob/1.8.1.Final/extensions/micrometer/runtime/src/main/java/io/quarkus/micrometer/runtime/export/handlers/PrometheusHandler.java#L34
The thing is that there are now potentially two distinct handlers living on the same /metrics endpoint. Vert.x chooses the handler based on this produces value, and if we left this value as text/plain; version=0.0.4; charset=utf-8, then it would only be matched if the client sent an Accept header with this whole value. So if the client requested Accept: text/plain there would be no matched handler to handle the request.

Aha, now I remember that.
Thanks for the explanation!
